channel.title: Jan
channel.description: Day By Day VA Family-Literacy Calendar

item.title: January Monthly Activities
item.description:
Books to Read!

• Mr. Putter and Tabby Catch the Cold by Cynthia Rylant and Arthur Howard
• Henry and Mudge Get the Cold Shivers by Cynthia Rylant
• How To Catch A Cold by Adam T. Newman and Susan G. Young
• Doc McStuffins: Chilly Catches A Cold by Sheila Sweeny Higginson
• Cold Paws, Warm Heart by Madeleine Floyd
• My Cold Plum Lemon Pie Bluesy Mood by Tameka Fryer Brown and Shane Evans
• Dora's Chilly Day by Ellen Rosebrough and M. J. Illustrations
• Buster Catches A Cold by Hisako Madokoro
• Animals In Winter by Henrietta Bancroft, Richard G. Van Gelder, and Helen K. Davie
• Katie Caught A Cold by Charlotte Cowan, M. D.
• Winter Is Here! by Heidi Pross Gray
• Let It Snow by Maryann Cocea-Leffler
• Ten On the Sled by Kim Norman and Liza Woodruff
• Winter Is Coming by Tony Johnston and Jim LaMarche
• The Winter Train by Susanna Isern and Ester Garcia
• The Mitten by Jan Brett
• Just A Snowman by Mercer Mayer
• Peeper Has a Fever by Charlotte Cowan, M. D.
• The Biggest Snowman Ever by Steven Kroll
• Wonderful Gifts of Winter by Dandi Mackall and Katherine Blackmore
• Sadie's Sore Throat by Charlotte Cowan, M. D.
• Winter Is For Snow by Robert Neubecker
• Biscuit's Snowy Day by Alyssa Capucilli, Pat Schories, and Mary O'Keefe Young
• Snowmen At Night by Carolyn Buchner
• Tacky and the Winter Games by Helen Lester and Lynn Munsinger
• The Long Winter by Laura Ingalls Wilder and Garth Williams
• When Winter Comes by Nancy Van Laan and Susan Gaber
• Winter According To Humphrey by Betty G. Birney
• 12 Snow Days of Winter by E. W. Turner
• Winter Bees and Other Poems of the Cold by Joyce Sidman and Rick Allen

Artwork by Murphy iREAD 2014 Summer Reading Program

Around VA

Check out Festivals and Events happening in January around the state. There are several chilly winter runs this month—perfect for whole families to walk or run together to stay active and healthy. Here are several that will be in January:

  • MOCA Art Show at 2nd Annual Coastal Virginia Wine Fest - Virginia Beach
  • DMV Vendor and Craft Fair - Richmond
  • Greater Roanoke Home and Garden Show - Roanoke
  • Hampton World's Greatest Hobby On Tour - Hampton
  • DC Big Flea Market - Chantilly
  • Virginia Farm Show - Fishersville
  • 29th Annual Washington Camping RV Expo - Chantilly
  • DC Tattoo Expo - Arlington
  • MarsCon - Williamsburg
  • Richmond Fishing Expo - Doswell
  • Salem Winter Gun and Knife Show - Salem
  • Richmond Jewish Food Festival - Richmond
  • Fredericksburg Boat Show - Fredericksburg
  • Fishersville Winter Gun Show - Fishersville
  • Tidewater Winter Gun and Knife Show - Norfolk
  • Winter Blast Wedding Show - Newport News
  • Sugarloaf Crafts Festival - Chantilly
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 31
item.description:
Sing a Song

Little Elf (To the tune of If You're Happy and You Know It)

There's a little elf that's sitting on my nose,
There's a little elf that's sitting on my nose.
He is sitting on my nose,
Then off away he goes.
Now there's no little elf on my nose,

There's a little elf that's sitting on my knee,
There's a little elf that's sitting on my knee.
He is sitting on my knee,
Just watch and he will flee.
Now there's no little elf on my knee.

There's a little elf that's sitting on my head,
There's a little elf that's sitting on my head.
He is sitting on my head,
Then away he goes to bed.
Now there's no little elf on my head.

Watch

Little Elf

Try This

You will need scissors, assorted colors or construction paper, markers, and glue or glue stick. First, print out a photo of your child and cut out the face and a little above the hair line. You could make your child have point ears if you really want to make them look 'elfish." Cut out a hat shape, a small yellow circle (for the bell), and a brim. For the body, start with a rectangle. Use your imagination with the embellishments to add pockets, belt, etc. For the arms and legs, cut a wide strip the length of the paper. Fold the strip accordion style, then cut the strip in half to get get two long, folded strips. Cut two more strips for the legs. Glue one end on each side of the body, and the other two under the body. Cut two mittens or hands, and glue them on the ends of the arms. Cut out some elf shoes and glue them to the ends of the legs. Cut two brims and glue them to the top of the shoes. Cut out two yellow circles and glue them to the tips of the shoes. You can make an elf for the whole family. Have fun! See http://www.artsyfartsymama.com/2013/12/diy-elf-kids-craft.html for images.

TumbleBooks

The Littlest Elf - Brandi Daugherty and Kirsten Richards

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • Café Zoom - 20 Elf on the Shelf crafts your family will love.
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 30
item.description:
Sing A Song

I'm A Little Snoman

Tune: I'm A Little Tea Pot

Key Gesture: Put your hands on your hips with your elbows out wide, making one circle.
Bend your knees outward, making another circle with your legs.
See

Watch

Watch

" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen>

I'm A Little Snowman

Try This

Create a snowman out of three large circles of paper or cardboard and tape it to a wall before class. Put about 10-15 buttons of various sizes and colors in a small bag. Have the students sit in a circle. Pass the bag around the circle and have the students try to guess what is inside. Take the buttons out of the bag and talk about all of the different sizes and colors. ("Look, this is a big, yellow button! Here's a small, black button.") Tell the students you are going to make the eyes, nose, mouth, and buttons for the snowman using these buttons. Choose one student and say, "Can you put on one eye?" The student chooses a button and, with some adhesive putty on the back, sticks the button on the snowman to make an eye. Continue with the other eye, mouth, and buttons. For the last piece, the nose, let each student try to put the nose on the snowman while wearing a blindfold!

TumbleBooks

Snowmen At Night by Caralyn Buehner and Mark Buehner

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • Draw A Snowman With Your Eyes Closed - You Will Need: A paper and pencil for each player and a blindfold for younger players (older players may be trusted to keep their eyes shut!). How to Play: Give everyone a piece of paper and pencil and blindfold if necessary. Tell them to close their eyes and draw what you tell them to. Don't tell them what they will be drawing. Draw three circles on top of each other, starting with a small circle at the top and getting bigger each time. Draw three buttons down the middle of the middle circle. Draw two eyes, a carrot nose and a mouth on the top circle. Add a hat. Add to stick arms and hands to either side of the middle circle. Draw a broom in one of the stick hands." When everyone has finished their drawing, they can open their eyes and compare! Award a prize to the best drawing and a booby prize to the funniest.
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 29
item.description:
Sing A Song

Dance Like Snowflakes

Tune: Frere Jacques/Are You Sleeping? (See Dance Like Snowflakes)

Dance like snowflakes.
Dance like snowflakes.
In the air.
In the air.
Whirling ,twirling snowflakes.
Whirling, twirling snowflakes.
Here and there.
Here and there.

Watch

Dance Like Snowflakes

Try This

You will need 2 silver pipecleaners and 3 blue pipecleaners. Cut the two silver pipe cleaners in half. Put one piece aside so you have 3. Twist these three pieces together in the centre so that you have a shape with six points (look at the photo above for help with this). Cut the blue pipe cleaners in half and then in half again. You will have 12 pieces. Twist these on to the silver base to decorate your snowflake. If you want to hang your snowflake, take the piece of silver pipe cleaner you put aside, fold in half and twist the ends to one of the snowflake points to make a loop.

TumbleBooks

Snowflakes Fall by

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • Snowflake Facts for Kids Teach kids fun and interesting facts about snow and snowflakes.
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 28
item.description:
Sing a Song

Five Little Snowmen

Five Little Snowmen.

5 little snowmen standing in a row (hold up 5 fingers)
Each with a hat (pat head) and a big red bow (pull at neck like a bow tie)
Along came the sun (arms form big circle over head) and it shone all day(lean to the left)
And one of those snowmen melted away! (put down one finger)
Continue until there are no snowmen left.
Version Two:
Five little snowmen standing in a row. (hold up five fingers)
They each have a hat (hands on head)
And a big red bow (hands on neck)
When the sun shines, (circle arms overhead)
Where will they go? (shrug shoulders)
They melt, melt, melt, melt... (sink down to the floor)
Version Three:
Tune: Five Little Ducks Went Out One Day
Five little snowmen all made of snow,
Five little snowmen standing in a row,
Out came the sun and stayed all day,
And one little snowman melted away.
Repeat until no snowmen are left.
Version Four:
Five little snowpeople were standing in a row
Each wore a hat and a big red bow.
Out came the sun and it was hot all day.
One little snowman (woman) melted away.
Repeat with 4, 3, 2, 1 little snowpeople.

Watch

Five Little Snowmen

Try This

Indoor Ice Skating

All you need is some wax paper, rubber bands, and carpet. Be careful, as it's quite slippery but lots of fun!

TumbleBooks

Pinkalicious: Pink Around the Rink by Victoria Kann

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • 9 Interesting Facts About Snow
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 27
item.description:
Sing a Song

Pease Porridge

It’s Mother Goose time. There is a rhyme called Pease Porridge. You can clap along.

Pease Porridge hot,
Pease Porridge cold.
Pease Porridge in the pot,
Nine days old.

Do you know what porridge is? What about oatmeal? What about cereal? What do you like to eat for breakfast?

Try This

Make a Nutrition Train! The body works like a "nutrition train."

Along the way, whatever children eat gets loaded onto to the train. Bad food eating, like greasy pizza and high fat cheeseburgers, slows the train down. Healthy foods like vegetables and fruits speeds the train up and help it work correctly.

Help your child create his or her very own Nutrition Train and work together to draw the good things that are part of the train.

TumbleBooks

Yancy and Bear - Hazel Hutchins

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Watch

Sesame Street: Jack Be Tired, Jack Be Slow

Explore More

  • Ready, Set, Breakfast! - Find out what you and your child can eat for breakfast to make your day great!
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 26
item.description:
Sing a Song

We Can Jump

It is good to be healthy. Jumping around and exercising can be fun! Here is a song you can sing while you jump and play!

We can jump, jump, jump!
We can hop, hop, hop!
We can clap, clap, clap!
We can stop, stop, stop!
We can nod our heads for "Yes",
We can shake our heads for "No".
We can bend our knees a little bit,
And sit....down....slow

Watch

Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes

Try This

Exercise by giving your child a sequence of two things to do such as "Jump up, then sit down." Then increase to three things such as "Touch your nose, turn around, and then sit down." Also sing "Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes" to keep that energy up!

TumbleBooks

Wiggle - Doreen Cronin

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • PBS KIDS Sprout: Stretches - You and your child can do stretches together. Try a stretch first thing in the morning or right before bed.
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 25
item.description:
Sing a Song

In Our Backyard

Tune: Mulberry Bush

This is the way we bounce a balloon
Bounce a balloon, bounce a balloon.
This is the way we bounce a balloon,
In our backyard.

This is the way we ring a bell
Ring a bell, ring a bell.
This is the way we ring a bell,
In our backyard.

This is the way we fly like a bat
Fly like a bat, fly like a bat.
This is the way we fly like a bat,
In our backyard.

This is the way we sing like a bird
Sing like a bird, sing like a bird.
This is the way we sing like a bird,
In our backyard.

This is the way we eat a banana
Eat a banana, eat a banana.
This is the way we eat a banana,
In our backyard.

This is the way we bounce a ball
Bounce a ball, bounce a ball.
This is the way we bounce a ball,
In our backyard.

What else can you do in your backyard?

Watch

Music Time with Steve Songs

Try This

Let your child play a game outside, like Tag, Kick the Can, Hide and Go Seek. If it is too cold to be outside, then exercise by putting on music and dancing quickly. Talk together about some of your favorite songs.

TumbleBooks

Stretch - Doreen Cronin

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • Kids Public Radio - Listen to three radio stations just for kids!
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 24
item.description:
Sing a Song

You already know that washing your hands is important to be healthy! Here is a song about GERMS!

The G-E-R-M-S Song

Tune: Frere Jacques

Are you coughing?
Are you sneezing?
Cover your mouth,
Cover your mouth.
Germs are always flying,
Germs are always flying.
Wash your hands.
Wash your hands.

Watch

The Journey of a Germ

Try This

Let your child make his or her own pretend first-aid kit for dramatic play with paper box, cotton balls, Q-tips, popsicle sticks, and cut-up gauze (or toilet paper.)

TumbleBooks

Big Or Little - Kathy Stinson

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

Use these two resources to make a family first aid kit.

  • FEMA for Kids: First Aid Kit
  • Kids' First Aid Kit
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 23
item.description:
Sing a Song

The Rules on the Bus

Do you ever see a bus? What does it look like? What color is it? Have you ever ridden on a bus?

When we wait for the bus we're on the sidewalk,
on the sidewalk, on the sidewalk.
When we wait for the bus we're on the sidewalk,
All around the town.

Getting on the bus we take our turn,
take our turn, take our turn.
Getting on the bus we take our turn,
All around the town.

The children on the bus stay in their seats,
Stay in their seats, stay in their seats.
The children on the bus stay in their seats,
All around the town.

Arms and heads stay in the bus,
stay in the bus, stay in the bus.
Arms and heads stay in the bus,
All around the town.

The children on the bus talk quietly,
quietly, quietly.
The children on the bus talk quietly,
All around the town.

The driver on the bus says listen to him,
listen to him, listen to him.
The driver on the bus says listen to him,
All around the town.

Getting off the bus we take our turn,
take our turn, take our turn.
Getting off the bus we take our turn,
All around the town.

Watch

The Wheels on the Bus

Try This

Practice Street Safety today.

You can go outside or if it too cold, then it’s ok to stay inside and practice. Talk about the right way to cross a street: hold hands, look left then right then left. Point out any safety signs along the way. You and your child can even make signs for inside the house.

TumbleBooks

Doors - Roxie Munro

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • Crossing the Street - This handout helps you teach your children safe procedures for crossing the street.
  • Safe Walking for Kids - Teach your child about street signs and pedestrian safety.
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 22
item.description:
Sing a Song

It is important to know your address and telephone number. Here are two songs to help you learn your information.

I Know My Phone Number
Tune: Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star

I know my phone number, yes, I do.
Listen now, I'll say it for you:
(YOUR TELEPHONE NUMBER HERE; for example 555 2323)
I know my phone number, yes, I do.
Listen now, I'll say it for you.

It's Important That I Know my Address
Tune: If You’re Happy And You Know It

It's important that I know my address,
It's important that I know my address.
If you listen to me now,
I will say it, I know how.
It's important that I know my address.
(Child says address at the end of the song.)

Try This

Talk about being safe and how important it is.

Make sure everyone in the family knows their name, address, telephone number and what to do in case of emergency. Be sure important information is in a child’s backpack or tote bag.

TumbleBooks

Scaredy Squirrel - Melanie Watt

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Watch

Sesame Street: Humpty Dumpty Helmet

Explore More

  • McGruff Advice - Check out this advice for keeping your family safe from bullies, in the house, and in the community.
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 21
item.description:
Sing a Song

The Very Hungry Caterpillar Song

Tune: Ten Little Indians

On Sunday, 1 little egg, on Sunday, 1 little egg,
On Sunday, 1 little egg, out comes a caterpillar.

On Monday, 1 red apple, on Monday, 1 red apple,
On Monday 1 red apple, that’s what the caterpillar eats.

On Tuesday, 2 yellow pears, on Tuesday, 2 yellow pears,
On Tuesday, 2 yellow pears, that’s what the caterpillar eats.

On Wednesday, 3 purple plums, on Wednesday, 3 purple plums,
On Wednesday, 3 purple plums, that’s what the caterpillar eats.

On Thursday, 4 red strawberries, on Thursday, 4 red strawberries,
On Thursday, 4 red strawberries, that’s what the caterpillar eats.

On Friday, 5 oranges, on Friday, 5 oranges,
On Friday, 5 oranges, that’s what the caterpillar eats.

On Saturday, too much food, on Saturday, too much food,
On Saturday, too much food, that’s what the caterpillar eats.

On Sunday, 1 green leaf, on Sunday, 1 green leaf,
On Sunday, 1 green leaf, that’s what the caterpillar eats.

In his cocoon, he goes to sleep, in his cocoon, he goes to sleep,
In his cocoon, he goes to sleep, that’s what the caterpillar does.

Out comes a butterfly, out comes a butterfly,
Out comes a butterfly, isn’t that a great surprise!

Try This

Make a healthy snack! How about Ants on a Log? You only need 3 things: celery sticks, peanut butter, and raisins

Fill the center of the celery stick with peanut butter. Place a few raisins on top to be your ants. If your child cannot eat peanut butter, you can use low fat cream cheese. Eat and enjoy!

TumbleBooks

Song Of Middle C - Alison McGhee

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Watch

Sesame Street: Healthy Meal

Explore More

  • Healthy Snacks for Kids - Keep these healthy and convenient snacks around for afternoon snacking.
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 20
item.description:
Sing a Song

Are You Eating?

Tune: Frere Jacques

Are you eating
Are you eating
Healthy foods
Healthy foods?
For your body needs them
For your body needs them
Everyday
Everyday.

Try This

Today you can talk about your food!

What color is milk? What does it taste like? What does it look like?

What about bread? What does it taste like? What does it look like?

Have you ever seen honey? What does it look like? Do you know where it comes from?

What about an apple? What does it look like? What does it taste like?

Talk about your three favorite foods.

TumbleBooks

Boy Soup - Loris Lesynski

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Watch

Sesame Street: Look What a Carrot Can Do

Explore More

  • Healthy Eating for Children - Learn more about healthy eating at each stage of childhood.
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 19
item.description:
Sing a Song

My Bubble Flew Over the Ocean

Sing a fun song about bubbles called My Bubble Flew Over the Ocean. Tune: My Bonnie Lies Over the Ocean

My bubble lies over the ocean.
My bubble flew over the sea.
My bubble flew over the rainbow.
Oh come back my bubble to me.
Come back, come back,
Oh come back, my bubble to me.

Try This

Mother Goose Time!

Little Miss Muffet
Sat on a tuffet eating her curds and whey
There came a big spider
Who sat down beside her
And frightened Miss Muffet away

Take a minute to think about this. Can you guess what curds and whey might be? Today we call it cottage cheese!

TumbleBooks

You See A Circus. I See… - Mike Downs

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Watch

PBS Kids: Healthy Snacks

Explore More

  • Polka Dots' Bubble Puzzle - Play this bubble puzzle online and spell words with Blue!
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 18
item.description:
Sing a Song

The Apple Song

It’s fun to sing about what we eat. Try singing The Apple Song. Tune: B-I-N-G-O

I know a fruit that's good to eat and
apple is its name, oh
A-P-P-L-E, A-P-P-L-E, A-P-P-L-E
And apple is its name oh.

I know a fruit that's good to eat and
apple is its name, oh
crunch-P-P-L-E, crunch-P-P-L-E, crunch-P-P-L-E
And apple is its name oh.

I know a fruit that's good to eat and
apple is its name, oh
crunch-crunch-P-L-E, crunch-crunch-P-L-E, crunch-crunch-P-L-E
And apple is its name oh.

Keep going until all the letters are crunched!

Watch

Way Up High in the Apple Tree

Try This

Talk with your child about the importance of vegetables to stay healthy. Try to eat 3 different vegetables today.

TumbleBooks

When Turtle Grew Feathers - Tim Tingle

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • Healthy Recipes for Kids - Bring your child into the kitchen to make these tasty and healthy meals.
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 17
item.description:
Sing a Song

I Am A Rocket

Let’s Pretend. Read the poem I Am A Rocket. Then act it out.

I am a rocket
crouched on the ground,
waiting quietly
without a sound.
Light this fuse
on my little toe...
Ready for take-off?
Here I go: SWOOOOOOOOOOSH

Watch

Making Maracas Out of Rice, Beans, and Paper Bags

Try This

Help your child make a noise maker out of pasta, cereal or any bits of something hard.  Place items in a paper cup and tape another on top. Use it to shake to the beat while singing rhymes!

TumbleBooks

Pecorino's First Concert - Alan Madison

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • Homemade Instruments - You can make musical instruments from household projects. Try the sand blocks, jingle bracelets, and juice can shakers.
  • Musical Craft Projects - Make these musical crafts and make your own drums, guitars, and more!
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 16
item.description:
Sing a Song

Ten Little Fingers

Do you know the Ten Little Fingers rhyme?

One little, two little, three little fingers.
Four little, five little six little fingers.
Seven little, eight little, nine little fingers.
Ten fingers on my hands.

Watch

Diez Deditos

Try This

Take the pictures from yesterday and put them on popsicle sticks or straws to make a puppet show about eating healthy. Have your child invite everyone in the house to participate.

TumbleBooks

Lola at the Library - Anna McQuinn

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • The Great Apple Slice Escape Reader's Theater - Here is a reader's theater script that you can use or adapt for a living room puppet show.
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 15
item.description:
Sing a Song

Right Hand, Left Hand

Here is a rhyme that also helps with learning coordination!

This is my right hand,
I'll raise it up high.
(right hand up)

This is my left hand,
I'll touch the sky.
(left hand up)

Right hand,
(show right palm)

Left hand,
(show left palm)

Roll them around.
(roll hands over and over)

Left hand,
(show palm)

Right hand,
(show palm)

Pound, pound, pound.
(pound fists together)

Watch

The Perfect Strawberry

TumbleBooks

Martin MacGregor's Snowman - Lisa Broadie Cook

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Try This

Have your child draw pictures of different vegetables and fruit and save them for tomorrow’s activity!

Explore More

Learn more about fruits and vegetables that you can add to your diet. Find some new ones for variety.

  • MyPyramid Fruits
  • MyPyramid Vegetables
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 14
item.description:
Sing a Song

The Bubble Song

Tune: Pop Goes the Weasel

Bubbles, bubbles in the air,
We're blowing lots of bubbles,
But when you catch one in your hand-POP! goes the bubble.
Way up high and way down low,
Floating in the air now,
But when you catch one in your hand-POP! goes the bubble.

TumbleBooks

Abra Cadabra and the Tooth Witch - Nurit Karlin

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Try This

Concentrate on showing your child how to brush their teeth really well. Learn the toothbrush rhyme:

I have a little toothbrush,
I hold it very tight,
I brush my teeth each morning,
And then again at night.

Watch

Sesame Street: Brushing Your Teeth

Explore More

  • Brushing Your Teeth - Keep your mouth healthy by brushing properly!
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 13
item.description:
Sing a Song

I'm a Fish

Tune: I'm a Little Teapot

I’m a little fishy, I can swim.
Here is my tail, here is my fin.
When I want to have fun with my friend,
I wiggle my tail and dive right in.

Watch

N: Your Name is Natasha

Try This

Read a poem called My Nose by Dorothy Aldis.

It doesn’t breathe;
It doesn’t’ smell;
It doesn’t feel
So very well.
I am discouraged
With my nose:
The only thing it
Does is blows.

TumbleBooks

Toilet Tales - Andrea Wayne von Konigslow

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • Photos of Fish - This government website has tons of fish pictures you and your child can explore.
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 12
item.description:
Sing a Song

My Garden

Read the poem called My Garden. Then read it again and do the hand motions.

This is my garden;
(extend one hand forward, palm up)
I'll rake it with care,
(make raking motion on palm with other hand)
And then some flower seeds, I'll plant
(planting motion)
The sun will shine
(make circle with hands)
And the rain will fall,
(let fingers flutter down to lap)
And my garden will blossom
(cup hands together, extend upward slowly)
And grow straight and tall.

Watch

I’m a Nut

TumbleBooks

Edgar, Allan, and Poe, and the Tell-Tale Beets - Natalie Rompella

Talk about seeds, plants, and how different vegetables grow.

item.title: January 11
item.description:
Sing a Song

Mother Goose Time!

Two little blackbirds
Sitting on a hill,
(pointer fingers up)
One named Jack
(One hand forward)
One named Jill.
(other hand forward)
Fly away Jack.
(one hand behind back)
Fly away Jill.
(other hand behind back)
Come back Jack.
(return one hand)
Come back Jill
(return one hand)

TumbleBooks

Ma, I'm A Farmer - Michael Martchenko

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Try This

Look at a map of South Carolina and find out where all the different types of crops grow. Discuss with your family if you can visit a roadside market stand this month.

Watch

Fruits & Veggies in a Grocery Store

Explore More

  • Commodity Map of South Carolina - What grows in the counties near where you live? Find out using this map.
  • Roadside Markets - Search for roadside markets in South Carolina. Are there any near your house where you can buy fresh fruits and vegetables?
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 10
item.description:
Sing a Song

Vegetable Fun!

Do you know what a carrot is?
Can you tell me what it looks like?
Do you know what a potato is?
Can you tell me how it feels?
Do you know what broccoli is?
Can you tell me what color it is?

Keep going describing as many vegetables as you can.

Watch

Crazy Over Vegetables

Try This

Cook a meal that includes your child's favorite vegetable.

TumbleBooks

Little Pea - Amy Krouse Rosenthal

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • Spatulatta.com - Find delicious recipes for the entire family!
  • Cooking with Preschoolers - Cooking can help young kids learn and practice math and language skills.
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 9
item.description:
Sing a Song

What some Letter L things you can learn about at the library? Come up with a few on your own, and then sing this song.

The Library Song

Tune: Mulberry Bush

This is the way I learn about lions.
Learn about lions, learn about lions.
This is the way I learn about lions,
At the library.

This is the way I learn about lizards.
Learn about lizards, learn about lizards.
This is the way I learn about lizards,
At the library.

This is the way I learn about lobsters.
Learn about lobsters, learn about lobsters.
This is the way I learn about lobsters,
At the library.

This is the way I learn about ladybugs.
Learn about ladybugs, learn about ladybugs.
This is the way I learn about ladybugs,
At the library.

Try This

Visit the library and choose books with your child about good health and eating well. Ask the librarian to help you find a cookbook for children.

Here are a few ideas to get you started:

  • Betty Crocker Kids Cook!
  • Cook It Together
  • The Everything Kids Cookbook
  • The International Cookbook for Kids
  • William-Sonoma: The Kid's Cookbook
  • The Berenstein Bears and Too
  • Much Junk Food
  • Brush Your Teeth Please: A Pop-Up Book
  • Green Eggs and Ham
  • Oliver's Fruit Salad Open Wide: Tooth School Inside

TumbleBooks

Something Good - Robert Munsch

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Watch

Nick Jr.: Cooking With Kids

Explore More

  • Children's Books that Encourage Healthy Eating - Check out these books from the library to get the conversation started in your family about healthy eating.

item.title: January 8
item.description:
Sing a Song

Twinkle Twinkle Traffic Light

Tune: Twinkle, Twinkle Little Star

Twinkle, twinkle traffic light
Standing on the corner bright,
When it green it’s time to go,
when it’s red its stop you know,
Twinkle, twinkle traffic light,
Standing on the corner bright.

Watch

Twinkle Twinkle Little Star

Try This

Exercise by playing tag or jumping rope. If it too cold outside, do some sit-ups together.

If you have a baby, practice bouncing on your knees. You can use the repetition to practice your alphabet or counting.

TumbleBooks

Little Hoot - Amy Krouse Rosenthal

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • Rainy Day Indoor Activities - Try these physical activities next time the weather prevents your child from going outside.
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 7
item.description:
Sing a Song

Sing a song about wearing the color Green.

If You Are Wearing Green Today

Tune: Mary had a Little Lamb

If you’re wearing green today
Green today, green today
If you’re wearing green today,
Please stand up.

If you’re wearing green today,
Green today, green today
If you’re wearing green today,
Please sit down.

(Can be used with any color!)

Watch

Kermit Sings Being Green

Try This

Today is a green day! How many kinds of fruit and vegetables are green? Try to eat at least one green food today!

(hint: try a green apple, green grapes, spinach, broccoli, or even an avocado)

TumbleBooks

The Lima Bean Monster - Dan Yaccarino

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • Fruit and Veggie Color List - Eat fruits and vegetables of every color!
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 6
item.description:
Try This

Talk about when to wash hands. Make a hand washing chart and put stickers on it for each time you and your child wash hands together.

You and your child should wash hands:

  • Before preparing or eating food
  • After going to the bathroom
  • After changing diapers or cleaning up a child who has gone to the bathroom
  • Before and after tending to someone who is sick
  • After blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing
  • After handling an animal or animal waste
  • After handling garbage
  • Before and after treating a cut or wound

Watch

How to Wash Your Hands!

{mp4remote}http://www.pkids.org/video/PKIDsHandwashingVideo.mp4{/mp4remote}

How to Wash Your Hands!

Sing a Song

Have fun with a Hand Clapping Rhyme!

Clap your hands 1, 2, 3
Clap your hands just like me.
Roll your hands 1, 2,3
Roll your hands, just like me!

TumbleBooks

Mud Puddle - Robert Munsch

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • Hand Washing Chart - Print a clean hands club chart for everyone in the family. Color or put a sticker in each box after you wash your hands.
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 5
item.description:
Sing a Song

Here’s a baby dance rhyme by Mother Goose!

Dance, little Baby, dance up high!
Never mind, Baby, Mother is by.
Crow and caper, caper and crow,
There, little Baby, there you go!
Up to the ceiling, down to the ground,
Backwards and forwards, round and round;
Dance, little Baby and Mother will sing,
With the merry coral, ding, ding, ding!

(try this song with the whole family, changing out Mother for Father, Sister, Grandma, and whoever else is nearby dancing)

Try This

Put on the radio, CD, or just sing and help your child make up his or her own tune. Everyone dance together.

Can everyone make up their own dance routine?

TumbleBooks

Wiggle - Doreen Cronin

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • Boowa & Kwala Songs - Listen to Boowa and Kwala sing and act out lots of songs! Can you dance along?
  • Do the Blue - Learn the dance movies and dance along with Blue from Nick Jr.
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 4
item.description:
Two Little Apples

Read this poem called Two Little Apples. Then read it again and do the hand motions.

Way up high in the apple tree,
(hold both arms up)
Two little apples smiled down at me.
(point to self)
So I shook that tree as hard as I could.
(shake hands back and forth)
Down came the apples!
(hands flutter down)
Ummmm, ummmm, they were good!
(rub tummy)

What is your favorite fruit? How many kinds of fruit can you name?

Help your child list or draw a fruit for each color in the rainbow.

TumbleBooks

Hoover's Bride - David Small

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Sesame Street: Eat Your Favorite Fruits

Explore More

  • Fruits & Veggies More Matters - This in-depth website has recipes, planning ideas, and ways to get your kids involved in eating a variety of fruits and vegetables.
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 3
item.description:
Sing a Song

I’m a Little Teapot

Sing I’m a Little Teapot. You can make up your own motions.

I'm a little teapot
Short and stout
Here is my handle
Here is my spout
When I get all steamed up
Here me shout
Tip me over and
Pour me out!

Watch

I'm a Little Teapot

Try This

Talk with your child about the importance of limiting the number of sugary foods you eat.

Have a "No Sugar" Day today.

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 2
item.description:
Sing a Song

Wash Your Hands

Sing the hand washing song!

Wash your hands,
Before you eat,
A good health rule,
That's hard to beat.
For better work,
For better play,
Eat three good meals,
Every day.

Watch

The Wash Hands Song with Danielle Howle

{wmvremote}http://web3.scetv.org/wash-hands/Wash-Hands-3min.wmv{/wmvremote}

The Wash Hands Song

Try This

Show your child the correct way to wash their hands.

  1. Wet your hands with running water.
  2. Apply liquid, bar or powder soap.
  3. Lather well.
  4. Rub your hands vigorously for at least 20 seconds. One fun way to count the time is washing hands for as long as it takes to sing the "Happy Birthday" song twice.
  5. Remember to scrub all surfaces, including the backs of your hands, wrists, between your fingers and under your fingernails.
  6. Rinse well.
  7. Dry your hands with a clean or disposable towel or air dryer.

TumbleBooks

Don’t Forget to Come Back - Robie H. Harris

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • Why Is Hand Washing So Important? - Find out why hand washing is the first line of defense against germs.
item.author: webmaster@lva.virginia.gov (Library of Virginia)

item.title: January 1
item.description:
Sing a Song

After a Bath Song:

(Make up your own actions!)
After my bath, I try, try, try,
To wipe myself ‘till I’m dry, dry, dry.
Hands to wipe, and fingers and toes,
And two wet legs and a shiny nose.
Just think, how much less time I’d take
If I were a dog, and could shake, shake, shake.

Watch

The Bath Song

Try This

During bath time talk about the importance of being clean. Make up your own bath song together!

TumbleBooks

Into the Tub - Laura J. Beaver and Jill P. Nolen

Access TumbleBooks and search for this book title.

Explore More

  • Make Bath Time Educational! - Try these simple ideas to make bath time a learning time.
  • Being Clean is FUNdamental - Join Sesame Street in learning about how to teach your child good basic hygiene. Don’t forget to watch the videos with the whole family!
